title: Welcome to my website!
text:
Github
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
I am Brooke Jurasius, a Ph.D. student in the Department of Pathology at Case Western Reserve University, specializing in Immunology. Under the mentorship of Dr. Carey Shive, my research focuses on understanding how inflammation influences aging, particularly in T-regulatory cells, and its implications for autoimmune responses and vaccine efficacy. Outside the lab, I enjoy playing golf, immersing myself in the beauty of classical piano music—Beethoven being my favorite composer—and spending time with my beloved cat.

title: Education and Research Experience
text:
Education and Research Background
I hold a Bachelor of Science in Biology from Santa Clara University (2023) and am currently pursuing a Ph.D. in Pathology with a focus on Immunology at Case Western Reserve University. My research under Dr. Carey Shive investigates how inflammation impacts aging in T-regulatory cells, with implications for autoimmune responses and vaccine efficacy.
Research and Laboratory Experience
In the Carey Shive Lab, I process peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) and have gained expertise in flow cytometry. One of my projects involves stimulating cells with IL-7 and inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, IL-1β, and TNF to study their effects on the regulation of homeostatic cytokine receptors. Since IL-7 is known to downregulate CD127, which initiates a signaling cascade that promotes T cell proliferation, survival, and differentiation, we aimed to determine whether other cytokines similarly downregulate CD127.
As a Process Development Intern at Pivot Bio, I validated primers for Bradyrhizobium bacterial strains, conducted qPCR experiments, and analyzed bacterial enumeration using qPCR and viable count methods. At Applied Molecular Transport, I performed ELISA and qPCR to study the IL-22 pathway, developed a new drug proposal, and analyzed clinical datasets.
During my time as a Research Assistant at Jasper Ridge Biological Preserve, I designed and refined protocols for DNA extraction and PCR testing from bird feather samples, conducting bioinformatics analyses to support conservation genetics. This diverse experience has equipped me with a robust background in molecular biology and data analysis, complementing my current research endeavors.

title: Education and Work Experiences
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Education and Work Experiences
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.
